ratings.comment: Pre-quarantine I found the course to be incredibly boring and not engaging. After, Professor Abramson essentially disappeared and stopped sending course material. She runs the course over email which is also quite bizarre. No canvas site. She also doesnt hold herself to deadlines AT ALL. Take a different capstone, the easy A isnt worth it.

An absolutely lovely person and professor. TAKE HER MOOD DISORDER CAPSTONE. Very doable workload, and no exams/tests! Grade is based on a (very low-pressure) 20 minute group discussion lead, and 2 papers that are (can't believe I'm saying this) a joy to write because of how interesting/fun/choose-your-own-adventure they are.

Professor Abramson is so incredibly nice and is passionate/knowledgable about mood disorders.  Lectures are very long, but bearable.  2 papers and 1 discussion make up entire grade.  Overall a good class to take, & I would recommend!
Easy class, but material and long lecturing can get dry. No tests just 2 take home essays and one presentation. Do not recommend taking when it is offered as a 2.5 hour classweek
Lyn Abramson is an outstanding respected Professor!
Professor Abramson is kind and humorous. Her class is wonderful.We did not only learn the empirical studies of affective disorders, but also the history and philosophy of them.

Prof Abramson is easily the nicest, most caring professor I've had at UW (I'm graduating in May)! Attendance was not required (but you should go!), no homework, no in-class exams. Your grade is based on two take-home (short) written exams. She's a very lenient grader as long as you put in effort. Not to mention, she's very well known in the field!

Lyn is one of the kindest and happiest professors at UW. It's expected that you attend every lecture since they're usually only up to 20 people each. No HW, no exams she reading is optional, 2 papers. She says to "write a paper about depression" and gives no guidelines whatsoever-they can be short,if you try to be creative you'll easily get an A
